author: Thabiso Mochiko
title: Mobile operators splash out on networks
text:
Picture: THINKSTOCK Related articles Mobile broadband licences to be auctioned, says Icasa MTN follows rivals’ lead and hikes prices Cell C to build 4G wireless network EDITORIAL: Slow off the digital mark Cell C to spend R8bn to build super-fast 4G network Fibre-optic demand sparks hiring spree Vodacom | MTN Companies and organisations: Cell C MTN VOD THE country’s top three mobile network operators are spending a total of R1.8bn on high-speed networks in KwaZulu-Natal and the Western Cape.
The investments in the network, which includes 4G and optic fibre cables to the home, will lift internet speeds.
MTN said on Tuesday it was investing about R1.2bn to upgrade its network in KwaZulu-Natal, which includes the deployment of fibre-to-the-home in the Durban suburb of La Lucia. MTN’s announcement comes days after Cell C said it was spending R427m in the Western Cape. Vodacom is also spending R180m in selected areas in the Western Cape.
Last year Vodacom completed a R1bn network investment in the Western Cape to increase speed, capacity, range and improve signal clarity.
MTN said its high-speed network, which was capable of delivering speeds of up to 100 megabits per second, would provide residents in La Lucia with multiple benefits including the ability to stream high-definition videos, play online games, home automation and the remote surveillance of their homes and businesses.
Global research firm Ovum stated in a report released on Monday that the majority of fixed-line consumer broadband users surveyed in 30 countries including SA, needed a download speed of at least 10 megabits per second.
Michael Philpott, co-author of the report, said "demand on broadband services provided to consumers is compounded by the rise in connected devices".
"Homes in mature markets were found to typically have up to four devices connected to the network, all of which have the potential to support a wide range of applications," he said.
